{{Advert|date=November 2016}} '''Omni-ID''' is a vendor of passive UHF [[Radio-frequency identification]] (RFID) tags. Founded in 2007 {{cite web|url=http://www.rfidnews.org/2008/02/12/omni-id-announces-itself-to-rfid-world-appoints-new-president?tag=Retail |title=QinetiQ launches new technology venture fund in partnership with Coller Capital, RFID News, Jun 27, 2007 |publisher=Rfidnews.org |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} as Omni-ID, Ltd., its products are a range of RFID tags designed to operate in all environments, including on metal and liquids. {{Infobox company | name = Omni-ID, Ltd. | logo = Omni ID logo.jpg | type = [[Private company|Private]] | genre = | foundation = 2007 | founder = | location_city = [[Rochester, New York]] | location_country = [[United States]] | location = | locations = | area_served = | key_people = President and CEO: George E. Daddis, Jr. PhD
Managing Director, Europe: Tony Kington | industry = [[Radio-frequency identification]] | products = RFID Tags | services = | revenue = | operating_income = | net_income = | owner = | num_employees = | parent = | divisions = | subsid = | slogan = | homepage = http://www.omni-id.com | footnotes = | intl = }} == History == === Founding === The company is based on a research unit that was formed within [[QinetiQ]], an international defence technology company that was spun off from the former UK government agency [[Defence Evaluation and Research Agency]] (DERA) when it was split up in June 2001. One of the problems the research unit studied was the difficulty reading radio frequency identification (RFID) tags placed close to metals and liquids.{{cite web|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/Xplore/login.jsp?url=http%3A%2F%2Fieeexplore.ieee.org%2Fiel5%2F10171%2F32491%2F01516541.pdf&authDecision=-203 |title=Environmental effects on RFID tag antennas, 2005 IEEE MTT-S International, Jun 2005 |publisher=Ieeexplore.ieee.org |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://pserie.psu.edu/outreach/rfid/Documents/RFIDresearchPSU.pdf |title=Microsoft Word - Dewolf_Maloni_ResearchPaperFINAL.doc |format=PDF |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} On August 22, 2007, Omni-ID was granted UK patent number GB2429878 for an “electromagnetic radiation decoupler.{{cite web|url=http://www.ipo.gov.uk/types/patent/p-os/p-find/p-find-number |title=United Kingdom Intellectual Property Office |publisher=Ipo.gov.uk |date=2009-09-08 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} With a working RFID tag that overcame those difficulties, it was decided to commercialize the design by forming a new company, Omni-ID, Ltd., which was launched in March 2007. Initial funding for Omni-ID was provided by Cody Gate Ventures LLP {{cite web|url=http://www.qinetiq.com/home/newsroom/news_releases_homepage/2007/2nd_quarter/qinetiq_launches_new.html |title=QinetiQ launches new technology venture fund in partnership with Coller Capital, Jun 27, 2007 |publisher=Qinetiq.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} a technology venture fund created in 2007 by [[QinetiQ]] and [http://www.collercapital.com/ Coller Capital]. An additional $15 million in Series C funding was provided to Omni-ID by Cody Gate Ventures in February 2009.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS171059+09-Feb-2009+MW20090209 |title=Omni-ID Secures $15 Million in Series C Funding From Cody Gate Ventures, Reuters, Feb 2009 |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} === Products === The core principle of the new passive {{cite web|url=http://www.technovelgy.com/ct/Technology-Article.asp?ArtNum=47 |title=Technovlegy |publisher=Technovelgy.com |date=2006-11-21 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} RFID tag design marketed by Omni-ID was that it contained a complex and proprietary arrangement of metal layers within the tag which reflected and boosted the signal broadcast from an RFID reader.{{cite web|url=http://www.technovelgy.com/ct/Technology-Article.asp?ArtNum=54 |title=Technovlegy |publisher=Technovelgy.com |date=2006-11-21 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} This allowed the tag to be read accurately even when placed on metal, on a liquid container, or even when immersed. This was confirmed in independent testing in November, 2008.{{cite web|url=http://rfidwizards.com/index.php?page=shop.product_details&flypage=flypage_wiz.tpl&product_id=10&category_id=3&option=com_virtuemart&Itemid=561 |title=Product Review: Omni-ID Max |publisher=Rfidwizards.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://rfidwizards.com/index.php?page=shop.product_details&flypage=flypage_wiz.tpl&product_id=2&category_id=3&option=com_virtuemart&Itemid=561 |title=Product Review: Omni-ID Flex |publisher=Rfidwizards.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://rfidwizards.com/index.php?page=shop.product_details&flypage=flypage_wiz.tpl&product_id=1&category_id=3&option=com_virtuemart&Itemid=561 |title=Product Review: Omni-ID Prox |publisher=Rfidwizards.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} The company offers five different tag designs: Ultra, Max, Flex, Prox, and Curv. Each has a different [[Radio-frequency identification|read range]], based on the trade-off between tag size and performance. The Ultra tag has the longest read range in the Omni-ID product family; up to 135 ft. with a stationary reader.{{cite web|url=http://m2m.tmcnet.com/topics/m2mevolution/articles/64353-omni-id-launches-rfid-tags-manufacturing-transportation-defense.htm |title=Omni-ID Launches RFID Tags for Manufacturing, Transportation, and Defense Industries |publisher=M2m.tmcnet.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} The Max tag has a long read range and is designed for tracking conveyances and outdoor assets. The Max HD is a long-range global tag for use in all geographic regions. The Flex tag is a thin, low-profile tag that offers a medium read range. The Prox tag is a small tag with a read range of 4m has the shortest read range and is often used for tracking high value IT assets. The Curv tag is a small, flexible tag for use on cylindrical assets. In October 2008, the company announced a new product, OmniTether, designed to attach RFID tags to items that lacked sufficient surface area for normal attachment methods.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfidjournal.com/article/print/4436 |title=RFID Journal, News Roundup, Nov 6, 2008 |publisher=Rfidjournal.com |date=2008-11-06 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} At the same time, the company introduced their Service Bureau product, intended to simplify the RFID tag commissioning process for its customers.{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS196433+14-Oct-2008+MW20081014 |title=RFID Innovator Omni-ID Unveils Service Bureau to Offer Flexible Tag Commissioning and Enhanced Customer Efficiency, Reuters, Oct 2008 |publisher=Reuters.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} Omni-ID prints a barcode on the outer label, along with human-readable information, and commissions tags prior to shipping so they arrive at the customer's facility with inventory and associated EPC coding on each tag. In November 2008, the company announced Omni-ID On Demand for their Prox RFID tag. The two-part product allows customers to print, encode and deploy Omni-ID tags as needed. Omni-ID has applied for a patent on the product.{{cite web|url=http://www.emqus.com/index.php?/emq/press_releases/omni_id_removes_barriers_to_rfid_adoption_through_a_patent_pending_on_site_deployment_solution_752 |title=Omni-ID removes barriers to RFID adoption through a patent-pending on site deployment solution, Enterprise Management Quarterly, Nov 17, 2008 |publisher=Emqus.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} In September 2009, the Ultra tag was introduced, a long range passive tag.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfidjournal.com/article/view/5213 |title=Omni-ID Launches New High-Performance UHF Gen 2 Tags, RFID Journal, Sep 14, 2009 |publisher=Rfidjournal.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} Benchmark tests by Martin Bjerre, RFID Global Solution, Inc., demonstrated a read range of 135 ft. with a stationary RFID reader, a record for a passive tag.{{Cite web|url=http://awareinnovations.com/2009/09/14/omni-id-launches-new-rfid-manufacturing-transportation-product-suite/|title=Omni-ID Launches New RFID Manufacturing & Transportation Product Suite|date=2009-09-14|website=Aware Innovations|access-date=2017-05-02}} === RFID Applications === [[RFID tag]] technology is used in supply chain management to improve inventory visibility and asset management tracking.{{cite web|url=http://www.ameinfo.com/66090.html |title=How RFID can help optimise supply chain management, AME Info, Aug 21, 2005 |publisher=Ameinfo.com |date=2007-05-27 |accessdate=2010-11-23}}{{cite web|url=http://www.emeraldinsight.com/Insight/viewContentItem.do;jsessionid=76719E207AF64D50B40197AFF4A2067E?contentType=Article&hdAction=lnkhtml&contentId=1611267 |title=RFID: an enabler of supply chain operations, Mohsen Attaran, Supply Chain Management: An International Journal, Vol. 12, Issue 4, 2007 |doi=10.1108/13598540710759763 |publisher=Emeraldinsight.com |date=2007-06-26 |accessdate=2010-11-23}} It is also used in [[Transponder timing|transponders that time races]], [[Electronic toll collection|vehicle access control]], [[biometric passport]]s, and in [[Library|libraries]]. ===Awards === In April, 2008, Omni-ID was a finalist and the second runner-up at the RFID Journal Awards.{{cite web|url=http://www.rfidjournal.com/article/articleview/4045/1/1/ |title=RFID Journal Awards, RFID Journal, Apr 2008 |publisher=Rfidjournal.com |date= |accessdate=2010-11-23}} Omni-ID was awarded the 2009 Asia Pacific Frost & Sullivan Technology Innovation Award for UHF RFID Tags.[https://finance.yahoo.com/news/OmniID-Awarded-2009-Asia-iw-14726388.html Omni-ID Awarded 2009 Asia Pacific Frost & Sullivan Technology Innovation Award for UHF RFID Tags, Yahoo Finance, Mar 24, 2009]{{dead link|date=November 2010}} == References == {{Reflist}} {{refbegin}} {{refend}} == External links == * [http://www.omni-id.com Omni-ID corporate website] {{Qinetiq}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Omni-Id}} [[Category:American companies established in 2007]] [[Category:Companies based in San Mateo County, California]] [[Category:Automatic identification and data capture]] [[Category:Radio-frequency identification companies]] [[Category:Information technology companies of the United States]]

{{Infobox organization |name = Open Source Ecology |image = oselogo.png |image_border = |size = |alt = |caption = |map = |msize = |malt = |mcaption = |abbreviation = OSE |motto = |mission = development of the Global Village Construction Set |formation = {{Start date and age|2003}} |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = |headquarters = Factor e Farm |location = Maysville, Missouri, USA.<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/Factor_e_Farm Factor e farm information] Accessed: 7/28/2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.google.com/maps/place/39%C2%B051%2750.4%22N+94%C2%B022%2730.0%22W/@39.864,-94.3793827,1267m/data=!3m1!1e3!4m2!3m1!1s0x0:0x0 |title=Google Maps Factor e Farm location |publisher=maps.google.com |accessdate=2016-04-05}}</ref> |coords = |region_served = Worldwide |membership = |language = |leader_title = ED |leader_name = [[Marcin Jakubowski]] |main_organ = |parent_organization = |affiliations = |num_staff = |num_volunteers = |budget = $4,000 monthly |website = [http://opensourceecology.org Opensourceecology.org] |remarks = }} [[File:Open Source Ecology, Practical post scarcity.ogv|thumb|right|Open Source Ecology: Practical post scarcity]] [[File:Global Village Construction Set.jpg|thumb|right|The 50 machines that compose the ''Global Village Construction Set'']]
'''Open Source Ecology''' ('''OSE''') is a network of farmers, engineers, architects and supporters, whose main goal is the eventual manufacturing of the '''Global Village Construction Set''' ('''GVCS'''). As described by Open Source Ecology "the GVCS is an open technological platform that allows for the easy fabrication of the 50 different Industrial Machines that it takes to build a small civilization with modern comforts."<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/gvcs.php "Open Source Ecology"], Accessed: 7-23-2011.</ref> Groups in [[Oberlin, Ohio|Oberlin]], [[Ohio]], [[Pennsylvania]], [[New York (state)|New York]] and [[California]] are developing blueprints, and building prototypes in order to pass them on to Missouri.<ref>{{cite news |author=Rohan Pearce |date=2011-12-14 |title=Can open source save the planet? |publisher=Techworld Australia |url=http://www.computerworlduk.com/in-depth/open-source/3325167/can-open-source-save-planet/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Leah Messinger |date=2011-03-23 |title=A Mad Scientist's 50 Tools for Sustainable Communities |publisher=The Atlantic |url=https://www.theatlantic.com/life/archive/2011/03/a-mad-scientists-50-tools-for-sustainable-communities/72900/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |author=Ashlee Vance |date=2012-11-01 |title=The Post-Apocalypse Survival Machine Nerd Farm |publisher=Bloomberg Businessweek |url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2012-11-01/the-post-apocalypse-survival-machine-nerd-farm }}</ref> The devices are built and tested on the ''Factor e Farm'' in rural [[Missouri]]. Recently, 3D-Print reports<ref>http://3dprint.com/10110/3d-printers-economy/</ref> OSE has been experimenting with [[RepRap]] [[3-D printers]] as suggested by academics for [[sustainable development]].<ref>J. M Pearce, C. Morris Blair, K. J. Laciak, R. Andrews, A. Nosrat and I. Zelenika-Zovko, "[https://www.academia.edu/1507915/3-D_Printing_of_Open_Source_Appropriate_Technologies_for_Self-Directed_Sustainable_Development 3-D Printing of Open Source Appropriate Technologies for Self-Directed Sustainable Development]", ''Journal of Sustainable Development'' '''3'''(4), pp. 17-29 (2010).</ref>
== History == Marcin Jakubowski Ph.D. founded the group in 2003.<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/about.php "About"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110717072826/http://opensourceecology.org/about.php |date=2011-07-17 }}, Accessed: 7-19-2011.</ref> In the final year of his doctoral thesis at the [[University of Wisconsin–Madison|University of Wisconsin]], he had the feeling that his career field was too closed off from the world's problems, and he wanted to go a different way. After graduation, he devoted himself entirely to OSE.
OSE made it to the world stage in 2011 when Jakubowski presented his Global Village Construction Set [[TED Talk]].<ref>[http://www.ted.com/talks/lang/eng/marcin_jakubowski.html "Marcin Jakubowski: Open-sourced blueprints for civilization"], April 2011. Accessed: 7-19-2011.</ref> Shortly after, the GVCS won [[Make (magazine)|Make magazine's]] Green Project Contest. The Internet blogs Gizmodo and Grist produced detailed features on OSE. Jakubowski has since become a [[Shuttleworth Foundation]] Fellow (2012) and TED Senior Fellow (2012).
In December 2013, Marcin married Catarina Mota. She co-chaired the Open Hardware Summit 2012, served on the board of directors of the Open Source Hardware Association, taught as an adjunct faculty member at ITP-NYU, and was a fellow of the National Science and Technology Foundation of Portugal.
Catarina finished her PhD dissertation on the social impact of open and collaborative practices for the development of physical goods and technologies. She was a visiting scholar at ITP-NYU, Research Chair at the Open Source Hardware Association, TED Fellow, and member of NYC Resistor.
Open Source Ecology is also developing in Europe as OSE Europe.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/OSE_Europe |title=OSE Europe |publisher=Opensourceecology.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref>
In 2016, OSE and the [https://www.openbuildinginstitute.org/ Open Building Institute] joined forces to make affordable, ecological housing widely accessible. The initiative has prototyped the [https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/622508883/open-building-institute-eco-building-toolkit/posts/1750160 Seed Eco-Home] - a 1400 square foot home with the help of 50 people in a 5 day period - demonstrating that OSE's [[EXtreme_Manufacturing|Extreme Manufacturing]] techniques can be apply to rapid swarm builds of large structures. Materials for the Seed Eco-Home cost around US$30,000. Further, OBI has prototyped the Aquaponic Greenhouse - which was also built in 5 days with 50 people:
Image: not letting me upload my own image at https://www.openbuildinginstitute.org/portfolio/aquaponic-greenhouse-workshop-2/ with caption ''Open source vertical growing towers with bok choi, lettuce, and other greens. Tilapia ponds under the towers provide nutrients as water circulates from the ponds to the towers. The ponds are 4 feet deep, making for a vertical biological zone 12 feet high to maximize productivity. The goal for the greenhouse is to experiment with the feasibility of producing a full diet for one person from only 800 square feet of space.''
== Factor e Farm == The '''Factor e Farm''' is the main headquarters, where the machines are prototyped and tested. The farm itself also serves as a prototype. Utilizing the Open Source Ecology principles, Marcin and Catarina have built four prototype modules which comprise their home. An added greenhouse demonstrates how a family can grow their own fresh vegetables and fish. Outside there is also a large garden including fruit trees..<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/Factor_e_Farm Factor e Farm Information] Accessed 7-31-2011.</ref>
==Current progress== As of 2014, twelve of the fifty machines have been designed, blueprinted, and prototyped, with four of those reaching the documentation stage.<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/Status_Brief Status Brief], Accessed: 2016-02-14</ref><ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/GVCS_Tools_Status GVCS Prototype Status], Accessed: 2016-02-14</ref> On October 2011 a [[Kickstarter]] fundraising campaign collected 63,573 USD for project expenses and the construction of a training facility.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickstarter.com/projects/622508883/global-village-construction-set |title=Fundraising |publisher=Kickstarter.com |date=2011-10-10 |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref> The project has been funded by the Shuttleworth Foundation<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shuttleworthfoundation.org/fellows/marcin-jakubowski/ |title=Marcin Jakubowski |publisher=Shuttleworthfoundation.org |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref> and is a semifinalist in the Focus Forward Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://vimeo.com/focusforwardfilms/semifinalists/51764445 |title=Build yourself. – Tristan Copley Smith |publisher=Vimeo.com |date=2012-10-19 |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref> <gallery> File:Powercube v7 Assembly.ogv|Powercube v7 Assembly video File:Liberator Compressed Earth Brick Press v4 Assembly.ogv|Liberator Compressed Earth Brick Press v4 Assembly video File:Open Source Ecology - LifeTrac - Design Rationale.pdf|LifeTrac tractor - Design Rationale File:Open Source Ecology - LifeTrac - Fabricaion Manual.pdf|LifeTrac tractor - Fabrication Report File:Open Source Ecology - LifeTrac - Fabrication Drawings.pdf|LifeTrac tractor- Fabrication Drawings </gallery>
==Awards and recognition== * In 2011, the project won the Green Project Contest organized by the Make magazine.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2011/02/open-source-ecology-interview-with-founder-marcin-jakubowski.html |title=Open Source Ecology: Interview with Founder Marcin Jakubowski |publisher=makezine.com |date=2012-02-24 |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref> * It was also selected as one of the 21 semi-finalists for the [[Buckminster Fuller Challenge]], among 162 participants.<ref>[http://challenge.bfi.org/2011Semi_Finalists The 2011 Buckminster Fuller Challenge Semi-Finalists | The Buckminster Fuller Challenge] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229091319/http://challenge.bfi.org/2011Semi_Finalists |date=February 29, 2012 }}</ref> * TIME rated OSE's Civilization Starter Kit as a top invention of the year 2012.<ref>{{cite news |title=Tech Best Inventions 2012 |url=http://techland.time.com/2012/11/01/best-inventions-of-the-year-2012/slide/the-civilization-starter-kit/ |publisher=TIME.com |date=2012-11-01 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121111090741/http://techland.time.com/2012/11/01/best-inventions-of-the-year-2012/slide/the-civilization-starter-kit/ |archivedate=2012-11-11 |df= }}</ref>
== List of machines ==
The Global Village Construction Set (GVCS) comprises 50 industrial machines:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://opensourceecology.org/gvcs.php |title=GVCS |publisher=Open Source Ecology |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/Global_Village_Construction_Set |title=Global Village Construction Set |publisher=Open Source Ecology |date= |accessdate=2013-02-07}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto; text-align: center" |- ! Category !! '''Global Village Construction Set (GVCS)''' |- | [[Habitat]] | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Compressed earth block]] press v4 {{·}} [[Concrete mixer]] {{·}} [[Sawmill]] {{·}} [[Bulldozer]] {{·}} [[Backhoe]] |- | [[Agriculture]] | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Tractor]]: LifeTrac v3 {{·}} [[Seeder]] {{·}} [[Hay rake]] {{·}} Micro[[tractor]] {{·}} [[Rototiller]] {{·}} Spader {{·}} [[Reaper|Hay cutter]] {{·}} [[Trencher (machine)|Trencher]] {{·}} [[Bakery]] [[oven]] {{·}} Dairy [[milking machine]] {{·}} Micro[[combine harvester]] {{·}} [[Baler]] {{·}} Well-[[drilling rig]] |- | [[Industry]] | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Multimachine]] {{·}} [[Ironworker (machine)|Ironworker]] {{·}} [[Laser cutter]] {{·}} [[Welder]] {{·}} [[Plasma cutter]] {{·}} [[Induction furnace]] {{·}} CNC [[Oxy-fuel welding and cutting|torch]] table {{·}} [[Rolling (metalworking)|Metal roller]] {{·}} [[Wire]] and [[rod mill]] {{·}} [[Machine press|Press forge]] {{·}} [[bearing (mechanical)|Universal rotor]] {{·}} [[Drill press]] {{·}} [[3D Printer]] {{·}} [[3D Scanner]] {{·}} CNC [[Printed circuit board milling|circuit mill]] {{·}} [[Industrial robot]] {{·}} [[Woodchipper]] / [[Hammermill]] |- | [[Energy]] | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Hydraulic pump|Power Cube]]: PowerCube v7 {{·}} [[Biomass to liquid|Gasifier burner]] {{·}} [[Solar concentrator]] {{·}} [[Electric motor]] / [[Electric generator|generator]] {{·}} [[Hydraulic motor]] {{·}} [[Nickel–iron battery]] {{·}} [[Steam engine]] {{·}} [[Boiler (steam generator)|Steam generator]] {{·}} [[Wind turbine]] {{·}} [[Pelletizer]] {{·}} Universal [[power supply]] |- | Materials | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Hall–Héroult process|Aluminium extractor]] {{·}} [[Plastics extrusion|Bioplastic extruder]] |- | [[Transportation]] | style="background:white; width:79%; text-align: left" | [[Car]] {{·}} [[Truck]] |}
==GVCS replication== During October, 2011 the first successful duplication of a Global Village Construction Set product by a third-party group was completed. Jason Smith along with James Slade and his organization Creation Flame<ref>[http://www.CreationFlame.org/ Creation Flame Main Page]</ref> developed a functioning open source CEB press.<ref>[http://www.creationflame.org/2011/06/eco-friendly-development/ Creation Flame progress] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120216025837/http://www.creationflame.org/2011/06/eco-friendly-development/ |date=2012-02-16 }} Accessed: 11/22/2011</ref> A group in Baltimore, Maryland, and a group in Dallas, Texas have also begun production of GVCS machines.<ref>[http://opensourceecology.org/wiki/Replication Other GVCS Replications] Accessed: 11/22/2011</ref>

{{Infobox website | name = Poll Everywhere | logo =File:Poll_everywhere_logo.svg | collapsible = yes | collapsetext = Screenshot | screenshot = Poll Everywhere screenshot.jpg | screenshot_size = 300px | type = [[Privately held company|Private]] | location_city = [[San Francisco]] | location_country = USA | foundation = {{start date and age|2007}} | key_people = Jeff Vyduna(CEO, Co-Founder)
Brad Gessler (Chief Technical Officer, Co-Founder)
Sean Eby (Co-founder) | industry = [[Audience response systems]] | homepage = [http://www.polleverywhere.com/ polleverywhere.com] }} '''Poll Everywhere''' is a privately held company headquartered in [[San Francisco]], California. The company, founded in April 2007 {{cite web|last=Lynch|first=Brendan|title=Startup Poll Everywhere invented the technology to conduct real time polls through cell phones|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2008/05/startup-poll-everywhere-conducts-polls.html|publisher=Boston Business Journal|accessdate= 27 February 2013|date=1 May 2008}} is an online service for classroom response and [[audience response systems]]. Poll Everywhere's product allows audiences and classrooms in over 100 countries{{cite news|last=Jenara|first=Narenberg|title=SMS Education: Poll Everywhere Is Making the Mobile Pop Quiz More Affordable|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/1693313/sms-education-poll-everywhere-making-mobile-pop-quiz-more-affordable|accessdate=28 February 2013|newspaper=Fast Company|date=6 October 2010}} to use mobile phones, thereby "plotting the obsolescence"{{cite news|last=Hoffman|first=Jan|title=Speak Up? Raise Your Hand? That May No Longer Be Necessary|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/31/us/clickers-offer-instant-interactions-in-more-venues.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0|accessdate=28 February 2013|newspaper=New York Times|date=30 March 2012}} of proprietary hardware response devices otherwise known as clickers. The company raised $20,000 in [[venture funding]] from [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] in 2008.{{cite web|last=Ha|first=Anthony|title=Y Combinator Demo Day: CO2Stats, Posterous and others show their stuff|url=https://venturebeat.com/2008/08/19/y-combinator-demo-day-co2stats-posterous-and-others-show-their-stuff/|publisher=Venture Beat|accessdate=27 February 2013|date=19 August 2008}} == Origins and History == [http://www.linkedin.com/in/jeffvyduna Jeff Vyduna], [http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=1710135 Brad Gessler], and [http://www.linkedin.com/profile/view?id=2517613 Sean Eby] were coworkers at [[Deloitte Consulting]] charged with giving internal presentations. One day, to keep the audience awake, they decided to pull a text message "out of a hat".{{cite web|last=Lynch|first=Brendan|title=Startup Poll Everywhere conducts polls through cell phones|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/boston/blog/mass-high-tech/2008/05/startup-poll-everywhere-conducts-polls.html|publisher=Boston Business Journal|accessdate= 27 February 2013|date=1 May 2008}} Code was started in April 2007, and the online site launched in September 2007. During that time, Vyduna matriculated at the [[Sloan School of Management]] at [[MIT]]. On May 14, 2008, the company placed as a semi finalist in the MIT $100K Entrepreneurship Challenge.{{cite web|last=Reidy|first=Chris|title=MIT $100K competition awards its top prize|publisher=Boston.com|date=15 May 2008}} Vyduna subsequently took a leave of absence when Poll Everywhere was accepted into [[Y Combinator (company)|Y Combinator]] in mid-2008; In 2010 the company moved to [[San Francisco]]. In September 2012, the company announced it had acquired competitors ClassMetric and TextTheMob{{cite web|last=Wan|first=Tony|title=oll Everywhere acquires TextTheMob, ClassMetric|url=https://www.edsurge.com/n/poll-everywhere-acquires-textthemob-classmetric|publisher=edsurge.com|accessdate= 27 February 2013|date=26 September 2012}} == Company == The company is managed by two of its cofounders: Jeff Vyduna, [[Chief Executive Officer]]; and Brad Gessler, [[Chief Technology Officer]]. The company earns revenue via monthly and annual subscriptions to its [[software as a service]] website. Bespoke development and onsite technical support are also provided to large enterprise customers and events. == Key Product Launches == * August 2008: US [[SMS]] [[short code]] support; and International expansion to Australia, Europe and Asia.{{cite web|last=Kincaid|first=Jason|title=Poll Everywhere Asks The Crowd To Spice Up PowerPoint Presentations|url=https://techcrunch.com/2008/08/18/poll-everywhere-asks-the-crowd-to-spice-up-powerpoint-presentations/|publisher=TechCrunch|accessdate=27 February 2013|date=18 August 2008}} * August 2011: Word Clouds for Open Ended Responses{{cite web|last=Byrne|first=Richard|title=Create Word Clouds in Poll Everywhere|url=http://www.freetech4teachers.com/2011/08/create-word-clouds-from-poll-everywhere.html#.US7Wkus4Ua0|accessdate=28 February 2013}} * December 2011: Full Featured Mac Presenter Release {{cite web|last=Rose|first=Michael|title=Friday Favorite: PollEverywhere Mac Presenter grows up|url=http://www.tuaw.com/2012/04/20/friday-favorite-polleverywhere-mac-presenter-grows-up/|publisher=Tuaw.com|accessdate=28 February 2013}} * March 2012: Support for Images and LaTeX in polling answers{{cite web|last=Byrne|first=Richard|title=Poll Everywhere Introduces Voting on Images|url=http://www.freetech4teachers.com/2012/03/poll-everywhere-introduces-voting-on.html#.US7GfOs4Ua0|publisher=FreeTechForTeachers.com|accessdate=28 February 2013}} * September 2012: Published the first comparison chart for web based audience response systems.{{cite web|last=Wan|first=Tony|title=Check This Out: A Comparison of Audience Response Systems|url=https://www.edsurge.com/n/check-this-out-a-comparison-of-audience-response-systems|publisher=EdSurge.com|accessdate=28 February 2013}} * September 2012: Published Mobile Tools for Presenters {{cite web|last=Byrne|first=Richard|title=Poll Everywhere Offers New Mobile Presenter Tools|url=http://www.freetech4teachers.com/2012/09/poll-everywhere-offers-new-mobile.html#.US7RNOs4Ua0|publisher=FreeTech4Teachers.com|accessdate=28 February 2013}} == Reception and Publication Mentions == * Mashable.com noted in 2008, "The Usefulness of Poll Everywhere is apparent." http://mashable.com/2009/06/17/poll-everywhere/ * Mentioned in ''[http://www.wiley.com/WileyCDA/WileyTitle/productCd-1118076877,descCd-buy.html Teaching Generation Text: Using Cell Phones to Enhance Learning']' l{{cite web|last=Nielsen|first=Lisa|title=5 Ways to Connect With Parents Using Poll Everywhere|url=http://theinnovativeeducator.blogspot.com/2013/02/connect-with-parents-using-poll.html|accessdate=28 February 2013}}" by [https://sites.google.com/site/teachinggenerationtext/ Lisa Nielsen and Willyn Webb] * Budget Audience Response Pick, Meetings and Conventions Magazine{{cite web|last=Braley|first=Sarah|title= A FEATURES Cutting-Edge Audience Feedback|url=http://www.meetings-conventions.com/articles/cutting-edge-audience-feedback/a38408.aspx|publisher=Meetings and Conventions Magazine|accessdate=28 February 2013}} * Mentioned in "[https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0470288930/ Teaching with Classroom Response Systems: Creating Active Learning Environments]" by [http://derekbruff.org/ Derek Bruff] == See also == * [[Audience Response Systems]] ==References== [[Category:Mobile technology companies]] [[Category:Y Combinator companies]] [[Category:American companies established in 2007]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]]

{{ref improve|date=October 2013}} '''Ramsbottom carbon residue''', which abbreviation is RCR, is well known in the [[petroleum industry]] as a method to calculate the carbon residue of a fuel. The carbon residue value is considered by some to give an approximate indication of the combustibility and deposit forming tendencies of the fuel.<ref>[http://www.kittiwake.com/Default.aspx/Page/KB/KB/29 http://www.kittiwake.com/Default.aspx/Page/KB/KB/29] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070622175521/http://www.kittiwake.com/Default.aspx/Page/KB/KB/29 |date=2007-06-22 }}</ref>
==The carbon residue of a fuel== The Ramsbottom test is used to measure carbon residues of an oil. In brief, the carbon residue of a fuel is the tendency to form carbon deposits under high temperature conditions in an inert atmosphere. This is an important value for the crude oil refinery, and usually one of the measurements in a [[crude oil assay]]. Carbon residue is an important measurement for the feed to the refinery process [[fluid catalytic cracking]] and [[coker unit|delayed coking]].
==Calculation methods== There are three methods to calculate this carbon residue. It may be expressed as Ramsbottom carbon residue (RCR), [[Conradson carbon residue]] (CCR) or [[micro carbon residue]] (MCR). Numerically, the CCR value is the same as that of MCR. Sometimes the carbon residue value can be listed as [[residual carbon content]], RCC, which is normally the same as MCR/CCR.
For the test, 4 grams of the sample are put into a weighed glass bulb. The sample in the bulb is heated in a bath at 553°C for 20 minutes. After cooling the bulb is weighed again and the difference noted.
==See also== *[[Conradson carbon residue]] *[[Cracking (chemistry)]] *[[Crude oil assay]] *[[Micro carbon residue]] *[[Oil refinery]] *[[Petroleum]]

{{Underlinked|date=April 2017}} [[Image:Ruudjan kokke-1493756847.JPG|thumb|right|Ruud-Jan Kokke]] '''Ruud-Jan Kokke''' ([[Velp, Gelderland|Velp]], 1956) is a Dutch designer who started his career in the mid-eighties and became known for his furniture, inventive objects, interiors and designs for public space.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://rkd.nl/en/explore/artists/45464|title=RKD website}}</ref> He has received numerous nominations and awards. He is married to the visual artist and jewellery designer Petra Hartman.<ref>https://www.petrahartman.nl {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170709175642/http://www.petrahartman.nl/ |date=2017-07-09 }}</ref>
==Career== Ruud-Jan Kokke studied at the Sociale Academie (College for Social Studies) and at the Academy of [[Artez|Fine Arts in Arnhem]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bear.artez.nl/nl/who/students-alumni/|title=Bear Artez alumni}}</ref> He is considered a designer in the tradition of [[Gerrit Rietveld]] developing his first chairs in his workshop.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.kunstbus.nl/design/ruud-jan+kokke.html|title=Kunstbus}}</ref> In 1986 he started his own label, Ruud-Jan Kokke Product & Design. Since then his furniture has been produced by companies such as Metaform, Leolux, Spectrum Design Eindhoven, Kembo, Auping and Ahrend. His first interior designs date from the early nineties. In close cooperation with his partner, Petra Hartman, he has also designed various school interiors.
==Objects== The Kokke chair designed in 1984, was first produced in series by Metaform in 1988 and can now be found in the permanent collection of the [[Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam]].<ref>http://www.stedelijk.nl/kunstwerk/814-kokkefauteuil</ref> It is made of flexible slats and has a transparent and strong structure. The notorious TC museum stool from 1990 was made for Museum [[Museum Boijmans Van Beuningen|Boijmans]] Van Beuningen in Rotterdam and is named after Trees Coenders, who was looking for a lightweight stool that was easy to carry and also easy to stack.<ref>http://www.dutchbydesign.com/tc-stool{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> It is now serving in several other museums and is collected by the [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMa]] New York under the title “Wander” Stacking Stool.<ref>https://www.moma.org/collection/works/3601?locale=en</ref> Four years later, in 1992, Kokke designed the Kokkestok, a walking stick which is easy to use because of the long curl, the stiff end and the rubber strip on the side.<ref>http://kokkestok.nl/</ref> Several other furniture designs followed, often in commission, such as the chairs for the restaurant of the Province House in Groningen in 1991, the Next bed for Auping (1996) and the Ahrend Run sofa (2009). In 2013 he developed Zami, an ergonomically designed stool, in close cooperation with the orthopaedic surgeon Piet van Loon.<ref>{{Cit web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/dft/ondernemen/grensverleggers/25234423/__Grensverlegger__Gezonde_kruk_ook__smart___.html#|title=Grensverlegger: Gezonde kruk ook ’smart’}}</ref><ref>http://www.zamilife.com/</ref>
==Interior design and design for public space== In the mid-nineties interior and public space became increasingly important. Often this concerned the upgrading of squares and parks or the renovation of existing buildings, such as the City Hall Arnhem (2007/2008) and several local Rabobank buildings.<ref>https://www.helldorferlasbedrijf.nl/stadhuis.html</ref> With the new millennium Kokke started a series of interior designs for schools, such as Mozaïek College Arnhem (2001/2002), Het Stedelijk Zutphen (2010) and Canisius College Nijmegen (2016), and sports facilities, such as Olympiaplein Amsterdam (2008).<ref>http://www.fritsnolte.nl/hekwerk.html</ref>
==Museum Acquisitions== *''Kruk TC [TC Stool]:'' [[Museum of Modern Art|MoMA]], New York, [[Cooper Hewitt, Smithsonian Design Museum|Cooper Hewitt]] New York; [[Museum für Angewandte Kunst (Cologne)|Museum für Angewandte Kunst Köln]]; Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam; Kunstgewerbe Museum Berlin; Design Museum Danmark *''Kokke seats'': Museum für Angewandte Kunst Köln; Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam *''Tray'': Museum Arnhem *''Moment'' [bench]:Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam;<ref>http://www.stedelijk.nl/kunstwerk/816-moment</ref> Museum Arnhem *''Kokkestok [stick]'': Museum Boijmans van Beuningen Rotterdam; MoMA New York; Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam *''Chair OT'': Stedelijk Museum Amsterdam<ref>http://www.stedelijk.nl/kunstwerk/17389-ot</ref>
==Exhibitions== *1994: Museum Für Angewandte Kunst Köln: Made in Holland, Design aus den Niederlanden *1996: MoMA New York: Thresholds, Contemporary Design from the Netherlands *2010: Lingam: Utrecht, Stockholm, Mons, New York *2012: Alliantie, Duo’s Ellecom
==Awards/Nominations== *''Kruk TC[TC stool]:''The International Contemporary Furniture Fair New York, 1992; Form ‘92, Frankfurt, 1992 *''Kokkestok [Kokke stick]'': Gelderland Design Award, 1994; Rotterdam Design Award, 1995 <ref>https://nl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rotterdam_Designprijs</ref> *''Moment [bench]:'' Good Industrial Design Recognition, 1995; Industrie Forum Design Award Hannover, 1996; Red Dot, Design Innovation Award of Design Centre North Rhine-Westphalia, 1996 *''Chair Harvink'':Dutch Furniture Award, 1997 (honourable mention) *''Fence'': Design to Business (audience award), 2008; Dutch Design Award, 2008 <ref>https://www.dutchdesignawards.nl/nl/gallery/product/hekwerk-olympiaplein-amsterdam/</ref> *''City Hall Arnhem'': Arnhem Willem Diehl Award, 2009 *''Kitchen'': MKB Innovation Top Hundred, 2013 *''Pavilion Stadsblokken Arnhem'': Dutch Sustainability Prize Steel, 2016
==Notable objects and projects== *1990: TC Stool, Museum Boijmans van Beuningen, Rotterdam *1994: Furniture, Design Institute Amsterdam *1991: Furniture, Restaurant Province House, Groningen *1997: Home Furnishing, (1160 student rooms) Wageningen *1998: Street Soccer Field, Amsterdam *1999: Home Furnishing (student and professor rooms), Leiden *2001: Mozaïek College, Arnhem *2003: Beekdal Lyceum, Arnhem *2004: Fence Olympia Square Amsterdam; Halve Maan Sports facility *2004: Brede School, Oosterbeek *2004: Parking facility, Pompekliniek, Nijmegen *2005/2014: Local Rabobank buildings (5 different buildings) *2007/2008: Renovation and restoration, City Hall and Square Arnhem *2011: T-huis Presikhaaf, Arnhem *2012: Design Pas dwellings, Het Dorp, Arnhem *2015: Bridges, balconies, balustrades incl. Coolhaven Rotterdam *2016: Summer Residence [pavilion], Stadsblokken Arnhem *2016: Folly Koningsberg, Rozendaal (Province of Gelderland)
==Publications== *Alphen, Frans van, ''Nooit meer met krukken langs de deur'', NRC 4 June 1992 *Horsham, Michael, Jennifer Hudson and Richard Sapper, ''The International Design Yearbook 1998'', London 1998, {{ISBN|1856691241}} *Houtenbrink, Erwin, Ida Jager and Johannes Niemeijer, ''Het meubelboek: Nederlands meubelontwerp 1986-1996'', Den Haag 1996, {{ISBN|9090101519}} *Lueg, Gabriele (ed.), ''Made in Holland, Design aus den Niederlanden'', Tübingen and Berlin 1994, {{ISBN|3803030617}} *Morgan, C. Lloyd (author) and Alessandro Mendini (ed.)''The International Design Yearbook 1996'', London 1996, {{ISBN|1856690806}} *Vöge, Peter and Bab Westerveld, ''Stoelen, Nederlandse Ontwerpen 1945 – 1985'', Amsterdam 1986, {{ISBN|9029081139}}
==References== <!--- See [[Wikipedia:Footnotes]] on how to create references using <ref></ref> tags which will then appear here automatically --> {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.kokke.com/ Website]

A '''shock tube detonator''' is a non-electric explosive [[fuse (explosives)|fuze]] or [[pyrotechnic initiator|initiator]] in the form of small-diameter hollow plastic [[tube (fluid conveyance)|tubing]] used to transport an initiating signal to an [[explosive charge]] by means of a [[shock wave|percussive wave]] traveling the length of the tube.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.shocktubesystems.com/allabout.htm|title=All About Shock Tube|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100209203102/http://www.shocktubesystems.com/allabout.htm|archive-date=9 February 2010|dead-url=yes|access-date=13 November 2017}}</ref> It was invented by Per Anders Persson of Nitro Nobel AB, patented,<ref name=pat3590739>{{US patent reference | number = 3590739 | y = 1971 | m = 7 | d = 6 | inventor =Persson, Per-Anders (Sodertalje, Sweden) assigned to Nitro-Nobel AB | title = FUSE }}</ref> and sold by them under the [[registered trademark]] [[Nonel]],<ref name=csi>[https://books.google.com/books?id=rjod-Lu6bHQC James T. Thurman, ‘’Practical bomb scene investigation’‘, p104]</ref> containing a small quantity of [[high explosive]], but safer and more reliable than [[detonating cord]] with the same quantity of explosive.<ref name=pat3590739/> Another early product contained an enclosed combusting, non-detonating fiber.<ref> {{US patent reference | number = 4220087 | y = 1980 | m = 9 | d = 2 | inventor = Posson, Philip L Assigned to Explosive Technology, Inc. (Fairfield, Calif. ) | title = Linear ignition fuse }}</ref>
The most common product is 3 mm outer diameter and 1 mm inner diameter, with a tiny dusting of [[HMX]]/[[aluminum]] explosive powder on the tubing's inner surface, which detonates down the tube at a speed greater than 6500 feet per second but does not burst the tube.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.shocktubesystems.com/drontey.htm|title=All About Shock Tube: A Review|last=Rontey|first=Daniel|date=|website=|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101101113435/http://www.shocktubesystems.com/drontey.htm|archive-date=1 November 2010|dead-url=yes|access-date=13 Nov 2017}}</ref> Being non-electrical and non-metallic, shock tubes are less sensitive to [[static electricity]] and [[radio waves|radio frequency energy]] and thus have replaced many uses of electric detonators and are safer to handle and store than detonating cord. A version containing an [[gas explosion|explosive gas mixture]] has the additional advantage of being entirely inert until the tubing is charged with the gas.<ref name=":1" />
One manufacturer estimates that over 2 billion feet of shock tube are used each year worldwide, in [[commercial blasting]], military [[demolition]], theatrical [[special effect]]s, automobile [[airbags]], [[egress systems|aircraft escape systems]], [[Improvised explosive device|IED]] initiation and professional [[fireworks]].<ref name=":0" />
==References== <references />

{{Infobox company | name = SIAE MICROELETTRONICA S.p.A | logo = SIAE_MICROELETTRONICA_S.p.A.png | logo_size = | caption = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = Headquarters in [[Cologno Monzese]] ([[Milan]]) [[Italy]] | type = Private | traded_as = | hq_location = [[Cologno Monzese]] ([[Milan]]) [[Italy]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = | industry = {{nowrap|[[Telecommunications equipment]]
[[Networking equipment]]
[[Communications]]}} | products = [[Backhaul (telecommunications)|Wireless backhaul]] and [[Fronthaul]] | num_employees = +1500 (2016) | slogan = | foundation = {{start date and age|1952}} | founder = Edoardo Mascetti | homepage = {{URL|www.siaemic.com}} }} '''SIAE MICROELETTRONICA''' is an Italian [[multinational corporation|multinational]] corporation and a global supplier of telecom network equipments. It provides [[Wireless network|wireless]] [[backhaul (telecommunications)|backhaul]] and [[fronthaul]] solutions that comprise microwave and millimeter wave radio systems, along with fiber optics transmission systems provided by its subsidiary SM Optics. Company products are deployed in more than 90 countries worldwide. The company is headquartered in [[Milan]], [[Italy]], with 26 regional offices around the globe.{{Cite web|url=https://www.siaemic.com/index.php/wolrdwide|title=Worldwide Subsidiaries|last=SIAE MICROELETTRONICA|date=|website=www.siaemic.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-05}} ==Corporate history== ===1952–1970s: Origins and initial growth=== Edoardo Mascetti, after graduating in 1949 in Electrical Engineering at the [[Polytechnic University of Milan]] and working as electronic designer for [[Siemens]], founded his own company and named it SIAE, acronym for Società Italiana Apparecchiature Elettroniche{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=YpQdfylmkWgC&pg=PA674&dq=siae+microelettronica&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y#v=onepage&q=siae%20microelettronica&f=false|title=Storia delle Telecomunicazioni|last=Cantoni|first=Virginio|last2=Falciasecca|first2=Gabriele|last3=Pelosi|first3=Giuseppe|publisher=Firenze University Press|year=2011|isbn=978-88-6453-243-1|location=Firenze|pages=674|quote=|via=}} The company manufactured measurement systems such as electro-mechanical testers, analog oscilloscopes, telephone system analyzers and signal generators. SIAE's sales volume in 1955 was 6.224.000 [[Italian lire]] and doubled by the end of 1957. A 431A-model oscilloscopehttp://fonologia.lim.di.unimi.it/strumenti_scheda.php?id=47 by SIAE was also part of the synthesizer in the [[Studio di fonologia musicale di Radio Milano]]([[RAI]]) until its dismissal on 1983 and is currently on permanent display with the original study equipment at the Musical Instrument museum hosted at the [[Castello Sforzesco]], [[Milan]].https://strumentimusicali.milanocastello.it/it/content/studio-di-fonologia-della-rai-di-milano [[File:Oscilloscope siae.jpg|thumb|SIAE Oscilloscope 431A (introduced in 1963) used for the synthesizer in the Studio di fonologia musicale di Radio Milano|246x246px|left]] A few years after founding SIAE, Edoardo Mascetti co-founded in 1958 Microelettronica S.p.A., a company whose business was the design of telecommunication equipment for radio and landline systems and which was initially located in a basement in Milan. In 1963, the two complementary companies were merged into SIAE MICROELETTRONICA S.p.A. and the headquarters was moved to the nearby town of [[Cologno Monzese]], where a larger area was available to accommodate the new offices and manufacturing plant. The new company counted less than 50 employees and focused its business on telecommunication systems, which were rising thanks to the capillary diffusion of telephone systems in Italy. [[Analogue electronics|Analog]] [[Multiplexing#Telephony|multiplexing]] systems for telephone providers constituted the company's principal product; nonetheless, in 1963, the company began an active collaboration with [[ENEL]], italian provider of electric power, in order to create a supervision system for the national distribution network, whose successful outcome later fostered similar activities in northern Europe and specifically in Norway.{{Citation needed|reason=|date=January 2017}} By the mid '60s, the company began actively promoting its products by advertising in technical journals as natural consequence of a growing business, thanks to its first large-scale commercialized radio [[transceiver]]: the 3-channel 3-B3 and later the RT450 (1966), capable of aggregating 48 channels into [[Ultra high frequency|UHF]] band. The RT450 equipment was also certified by [[:it:Telettra]] under the commercial name H450 as fallback link for its high-capacity solutions. [[Power-line communication]] systems were also manufactured by the company in those years along with the first fixed and mobile communication terminals in [[Very high frequency|VHF]] band (1972) for vehicular communications (precurring modern mobile phones) and anti burglar alarm systems. [[File:2.3GHz Modulator for RT12 radio transceiver.png|left|thumb|153x153px|2.3GHz modulator for RT12 transceivers, exploiting microstrip technology on [[Polytetrafluoroethylene|PTFE]] for connections and electromagnetic coupling for [[Electronic filter|filtering]] and [[Power dividers and directional couplers|splitting]] purposes (1978).]] By 1973, a whole new internal division was created for the design of television broadcasting equipments (repeaters and transmitters) whose main customer was the national television company [[RAI]]. The first television products were based on thermo-ionic tubes though the improvement of [[Solid State Logic|solid state]] technologies soon replaced [[vacuum tube]]s. Similar improvements in printed board manufacturing made [[microstrip]] circuits a viable solution for increasingly-high [[microwave]] frequencies and in 1978 the RT12 radio equipment boasted the first direct-conversion 2.3 GHz synthesized modulator and could aggregate 120 telephone channels. In these years, the company manufactured the historical link to connect the Milan and Rome branches of the [[Corriere della Sera]] newspaper.{{cite news|url=http://archivio.corriere.it/Archivio/interface/view_preview.shtml#!/NTovZXMvaXQvcmNzZGF0aW1ldGhvZGUxL0A1ODEzNw%3D%3D|title=Ingegnere e Partigiano, pioniere dell'elettronica|last=Manzoni|first=Franco|date=2004-06-02|work=|newspaper=Corriere della Sera|language=Italian|access-date=|via=}} The employees were about a hundred though the company still remained a family-run business lead by the founder and a tight board of managers through the '70s. [[Computer-aided design]] of electronic circuits was approached and exploited to improve yield and reduce the design time especially for the critical high-frequency sections.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HxlGAQAAIAAJ&q=siae+microelettronica&dq=siae+microelettronica&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwj1697xnqjRAhVGGhQKHfN5CN8Q6AEIQTAH|title=Digest: 1978 IEEE MTT-S International Microwave Symposium|last=IEEE Microwave Theory and Techniques|date=1978-01-01|publisher=Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers,|isbn=|location=|pages=88|language=en|quote=|via=}} ===1980s-2000s: Digital and worldwide company=== [[File:RT20 radio transceiver by Siae Microelettronica.png|thumb|374x374px|RT20 digital radio transceiver, carrying up to 30 telephone channels and operating at 0.9GHz of [[Carrier frequencies|carrier frequency]] (1981).]] The early '80s witnessed two intertwined aspects which boosted the activities: the digital revolution reached commercial radio links and the RT20 thus leveraged 4-QAM modulation in order to provide low-capacity links while the increased globalization opened up international markets and the company business expanded to Norway, Great Britain and gradually to Europe. A [[quality control]] system was soon implemented to meet and certify the improved production standards. In partnership with then [[:it:Telettra]], the Company developed the multi channel radio network covering the national extents, named RIAM, for the national electric company, [[Enel]]. The radio equipments were governed by a [[microprocessor]], in the wake of the widespread usage of these new components which offered a huge range of new possibilities for coordinating radio components when compared to traditional dedicated circuits. With the increased demand for traffic, higher frequencies were needed and in the second half of the 80's the company commercialized its 18 GHz radio transceiver with a capacity up to 2Mbit/s, based on specifications of [[Enel]]. A 13 GHz equipment with 4Mbit/s was instead first provided to the [[Mercury Communications|Mercury]] operator in the UK. [[Thin film]] manufacturing techniques for printed circuit boards were adopted during the 80s by the company for its microwave products beyond 10 GHz with ad-hoc equipments and production lines (yellow room) and soon upgraded to chip-and-wire technologies in white rooms ([[clean room]]). Documents show the RT28 transceiver remained in service until 2008 in the Italian [[Aosta Valley]].https://appweb.regione.vda.it/dbweb/bandigara/bandigar.nsf/(vediTutti)/8D8D6BF7C43F41ACC125753700499C07/$FILE/Capitolato_appalto_ponti_radio_2008.pdf?openelement [[File:Split-mount RT28 radio transceiver by Siae Microelettronica.png|left|thumb|18GHz RT28 split-mount transceiver, capable of up to 2Mbit/s communication (1986)]] In 1986 the Company introduced the "split-mount" configuration, where an indoor unit (IDU) is connected to an outdoor unit ODU. The IDU provides the network interfaces and carries out the [[baseband]] tasks while communicates with the ODU, usually by means of an [[intermediate frequency]], which is tasked of radio frequency up/down conversion and is connected to the antenna. The split-mount configuration is still currently in use in several modern radio products and the boost in sales at that time was recognized in the 1988 edition of Major Companies of Europe.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=bm4nAQAAMAAJ&q=siae+microelettronica&dq=siae+microelettronica&hl=en&sa=X&redir_esc=y|title=Major Companies of Europe|last=Graham|last2=Whiteside|last3=Blackburn|publisher=Graham & Trotman|year=1988|isbn=|location=|pages=402|quote=|via=}} In the early '90s the diffusion of data services and SDH required higher capacities to be transported and in 1992 the Company provided its HS13 SDH equipment to the SIP telephone company (later become [[Telecom Italia]]) entering thus the market of high-capacity microwave radio links and introducing enhanced techniques to counteract non-idealities in the communication channel and the transceiver hardware.{{Cite book|title=Fourth European Conference on "Radio Relay Systems"|publisher=Institution of Electrical Engineers|year=1993|pages=238|quote=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Baccarini|first=L.|last2=Biscevic|first2=G.|last3=Chiesa|first3=F.|last4=Miletic|first4=A.|date=1993-10-01|title=Error-correction techniques and adaptive linearization in SDH radio|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/264018/?reload=true|journal=1993 Fourth European Conference on Radio Relay Systems|pages=238–243}} Simultaneously, subsidiaries were opened in Latin America and Far East. To meet international standards for control and supervision of the increasingly complex networks of radio links, the Company developed its own [[Network management system]] providing a unified interface for all its products. One of the first versions of monitoring software was still in use as of 2012 for a [[:it:TETRA]] network.http://www.comune.torino.it/vigiliurbani/poliziamunicipale/struttura/comando/appalti/pdf/capitolato_servizio_progettazione_radio13.pdf In the meantime, the production of television transmitters and repeaters was halted in order to focus the activities towards the core business of backhauling radio links. The increased volume of chip and wire components fostered the introduction of improved [[Cleanroom]]s, upgraded to the 10'000 class. The Company further evolved internally to expand its business and offer the services surrounding the mere provision of hardware, such as network planning, assistance, installation and contributed to the activities of international standardization bodies.{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=IfZOAQAAMAAJ&q=siae+microelettronica&dq=siae+microelettronica&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwidgs-EoKjRAhXC1hQKHa_6BA84ChDoAQgdMAE|title=Report on the Activities of the International Telecommunication Union in ...|last=|first=|date=1994-01-01|publisher=The Union|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=73|language=en|quote=|via=}} In the late 90s the Company commercialized a family of products whose design was dedicated to the booming market of [[GSM]] [[Cellular network|cellular mobile communications]]. In 1999, the offer was expanded to support high-capacity SDH traffic and a number of multiplexing equipments were developed as well to address the increased complexity and demanded flexibility of network configurations and interfaces. ===Present day=== The Twenty-first century was inaugurated by the first direct collaboration and commercial relationships with China which in 2014 lead to a dedicated subsidiary, Siae Telecommunications Shenzhen Limited.{{Cite web|url=https://www.siaemic.com/index.php/worldwide/apac/china|title=China Subsidiaries|last=|first=|date=|website=www.siaemic.com|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-05}} The first european subsidiary opened in 2002 in [[Paris]] while the first non-european branch initiated activities in 2006 in [[Bangkok]]. The production and assembly processes began transitioning from manual to automatic [[SMT placement equipment]] in the early 2000s to cope with a volume of 15'000 radios/year while the yearly sales in 2002 increased by 25.8%.{{Cite news|title=Aziende di famiglia con una marcia un più|last=Vergnano|first=Franco|date=2003-10-25|work=Il Sole 24 Ore|via=}} In partnership with [[Cisco]], the Company developed algorithms and dedicated implementations for adaptive bandwidth and adaptive modulation schemes, which allow to react to impaired communication conditions (such as rain) gracefully reducing the link [[throughput]] instead of temporarily suspending the communication (out of service). Such solutions, extensively relied upon for [[Microwave Transmission#Planning|network planning]], are currently standard in most modern point-to-point radio links for backhauling.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/service-provider/unified-ran-backhaul/white_paper_c11-728355.html|title=Microwave Adaptive Bandwidth Feature: Make Better Use of Available Bandwidth|website=Cisco|access-date=2017-01-05}} In the wake of the global migration from [[circuit switching]] towards [[Internet Protocol|IP]] [[packet network]]s, the Company developed Full IP equipments in split-mount and full-outdoor versions and also dual native radios, supporting both [[Time-division multiplexing|TDM]] and [[Ethernet]] modes, whose popularity positively affected company's sales volume. To meet the ever-increasing demand for higher throughput without need for additional bandwidth, which is licensed at a price in most dedicated bands, frequency reuse dominated subsequent industrial developments and the adoption of [[Polarization division multiplexing|dual-polarization]] techniques was commercially proposed in 2007, when the company and [[Vodafone]] (Omnitel by that time) presented the paper "2xSTM1 frequency reuse system with XPIC" at the European Conference on Fixed Wireless Network Technologies 2007 in Paris.{{Cite journal|last=Rossi|last2=Calia|last3=Nava|last4=Salvaneschi|last5=Agabio|last6=Cornaglia|last7=Ratia|year=2007|title=2xSTM-1 Frequency Reuse System with XPIC|url=http://web1.see.asso.fr/cdecrr07/papers/S4B.5.pdf|journal=Proc. 8th Eur. Conf. Fixed Wireless Netw. Technol. (ECRR’07)|volume=|pages=|via=}} Thanks to Full IP and [[XPIC]] equipment sales, the yearly production of radios hit 70'000 in 2011 while the sales income topped 180 million Euro {{Cite web|url=http://www.reportaziende.it/siae-microelettronica_spa?anno3=2011|title=SIAE-MICROELETTRONICA - S.P.A. (p.iva 00779180157) - MILANO (MI) su reportaziende.it|last=Bordeaux|first=reportaziende.it - La Stanza|website=www.reportaziende.it|access-date=2017-01-05}} and by the end of 2012 the number of people employed by the company exceeded 1000 over the 25 world branches, about 700 of which located in the [[Cologno Monzese]] headquarters.{{Cite web|url=http://www.reportaziende.it/siae-microelettronica_spa?anno3=2011#a|title=SIAE-MICROELETTRONICA - S.P.A. (p.iva 00779180157) - MILANO (MI) su reportaziende.it|last=Bordeaux|first=reportaziende.it - La Stanza|website=www.reportaziende.it|access-date=2017-01-05}} The juridical literature reports of a litigation initiated in 2006 by NEC Corporation against SIAE Microelettronica over alleged [[patent infringement|infringement]] of several former's [[patent]]s in the courts of [[Milan]] and [[Munich]]. The case was closed in 2010 with a bilateral agreement to withdraw all infringement, nullity and opposition actions pending worldwide.{{Cite web|url=http://archive.eetasia.com/www.eetasia.com/ART_8800438490_499488_NT_b6f537a3.HTM|title=NEC files patent lawsuit vs. SIAE Microelettronica|website=archive.eetasia.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.siaemic.com/index.php/newsevents/news-archive/72-news-events/news-archive/138-nec-siae-microelettronica-litigation-settlement|title=NEC/SIAE MICROELETTRONICA LITIGATION SETTLEMENT|last=Laura|website=www.siaemic.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=qJ0nRwULEaAC&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=patent+siaemicroelettronica&source=bl&ots=zAF5e6sGWL&sig=-K9PlFGhKY4O4bLAmer6pV3UbtM&hl=it&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwii9dGKxPfMAhWF1hoKHQZFBkoQ6AEIIDAC#v=onepage&q=patent%20siaemicroelettronica&f=false|title=The Patenting Paradox: A Game-based Approach to Patent Management|last=Gasnier|first=Arnaud|date=2008-01-01|publisher=Eburon Uitgeverij B.V.|year=|isbn=9789059722309|location=|pages=58|language=en|quote=|via=}} Although not directly involved in antenna manufacturing, the Company and [[Polytechnic University of Milan]] patented in 2011 a dielectric antenna for mm-wave communications based on a novel design aimed at reducing the overall size, whose application targeted small [[Form factor (design)|form facto]]r radio equipments.{{cite patent| inventor-last =Magistroni| inventor-first =Claudio| inventor2-last =Cattaneo| inventor2-first =Oriano| inventor3-last=D'Amico|inventor3-first=Michele|inventor4-last=Gentili|inventor4-first=Gian Guido|inventor5-last=Oldoni|inventor5-first=Matteo| publication-date = 2011| title =Antenna dielettrica ottimizzata per trasmissioni a frequenze millimetriche| patent-number=MI2011A002141| url=http://hdl.handle.net/11311/646730}} The visual impact of transceivers began in those years to earn importance for the deployment of urban links, where the existing environment should be affected as little as possible by [[Mobile station|access stations]] and [[Backhaul (telecommunications)|backhauling]] transceivers with their [[Antenna (radio)|antennas]]. In 2013 the company entered the [[Extremely high frequency|millimeter-wave]] market with its full-outdoor transceivers in [[E band (waveguide)|E-Band]]. In 2014, the product portfolio included also [[V band]] radios for [[small cell]] backhaul and [[Non-line-of-sight propagation|NLOS]] solutions for urban communications which may benefit from exploiting reflections on buildings in order to increase coverage. A new network monitoring software was also released in 2014 to offer enhanced features to network operators for managing and evaluating aggregated [[Network performance|performances]], which are gaining more and more relevance as key figures in the assessment of traffic bottlenecks and overall behavior of a complex network.{{Cite news|url=https://www.techopedia.com/2/31633/networks/the-role-of-kpis-in-network-management|title=The Role of KPIs in Network Management|newspaper=Techopedia.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.it/books?id=ynyG9TB-tJ0C&lpg=PA48&dq=importance%20of%20%22key%20performance%20indicators%22%20in%20network&pg=PA47#v=onepage&q=radio%20network%20optimisation&f=false|title=Fundamentals of Cellular Network Planning and Optimisation: 2G/2.5G/3G... Evolution to 4G|last=Mishra|first=Ajay R.|date=2004-05-21|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|year=|isbn=9780470862674|location=|pages=48|language=en|quote=|via=}} In 2014 the labs for the management system for [[Backbone network|terrestrial networks]] and two families of equipment for fiber optic telecommunications—OMSN (Optical Multi-Service Node) and TSS (Transport Service Switch)— were transferred from [[Alcatel Lucent]] (now [[Nokia]]) to a new dedicated company, SM Optics, a subsidiary of SIAE Microelettronica.{{Cite news|url=https://networks.nokia.com/press/2014/alcatel-lucent-concludes-agreement-italys-sm-optics-transfer-specific-optical-research-and|title=Alcatel-Lucent concludes agreement with Italy’s SM Optics for transfer of specific optical research and development activities|date=2014-11-27|newspaper=Nokia Networks|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.lightwaveonline.com/articles/2014/12/alcatel-lucent-transfers-optics-r-d-to-italys-sm-optics.html|title=Alcatel-Lucent transfers optics R&D to Italy's SM Optics|website=www.lightwaveonline.com|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.ilsole24ore.com/art/impresa-e-territori/2015-02-18/alcatel-lucent-cede-altro-ramo-063755.shtml?uuid=ABBL6dwC&fromSearch|title=Alcatel Lucent cede un altro ramo|newspaper=Il Sole 24 ORE|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.repubblica.it/economia/2014/12/19/news/crisi_aziendali-103307729|title=Il governo festeggia le aziende salvate, ma a Natale restano 153 crisi aperte|date=2014-12-19|newspaper=Repubblica.it|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.corrierecomunicazioni.it/tlc/26741_alcatel-lucent-300-dipendenti-passano-a-siae.htm|title=Alcatel-Lucent, 300 dipendenti passano a Siae|website=www.corrierecomunicazioni.it|access-date=2017-01-05}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.corriere.it/notizie-ultima-ora/Economia/Alcatel-Lucent-trasferiti-asset-amp-tecnologie-ottiche-Optics/26-11-2014/1-A_015211664.shtml|title=ultimaora - flash news 24 Corriere della Sera|website=www.corriere.it|access-date=2017-01-05}} From 2014 to 2016, through its entirely owned company "Twist-off" in [[Padua]] (Italy), Siae Microelettronica was active in researching applications of [[Orbital angular momentum of light|Orbital Angular Momentum of light]] (OAM) communications applied to long-distance links.{{Cite conference|last=Spinello|first=Fabio|last2=Parisi|first2=Giuseppe|last3=Tamburini|first3=Fabrizio|last4=Romanato|first4=Filippo|last5=Mari|first5=Elettra|title=Laguerre-Gauss (LG) p-modes generation in the radio frequency domain|conference=International Conference on Orbital Angular Momentum (ICOAM)|location=New York (NY), USA|year=2015 }}{{Cite conference|title=Tailoring optical beam shape by superposing consecutive OAM modes|last=Parisi|first=Giuseppe|last2=Mari|first2=Elettra|last3=Spinello|first3=Fabio|last4=Tamburini|first4=Fabrizio|last5=Romanato|first5=Fabrizio|conference=International Conference on Orbital journal|last=Parisi|first=Giuseppe|last2=Mari|first2=Elettra|last3=Spinello|first3=Fabio|last4=Romanato|first4=Filippo|last5=Tamburini|first5=Fabrizio|title=Manipulating intensity and phase distribution of composite Laguerre-Gaussian beams|year=2014|journal=Optics Express|pmid=25090528|volume=22|pages=17135–46|doi=10.1364/oe.22.017135|bibcode=2014OExpr..2217135P}} Field tests of the principles were also published {{Cite journal|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2015RS005662/full|title=Tripling the capacity of a point-to-point radio link by using electromagnetic vortices|last=Tamburini|first=Fabrizio|last2=Mari|first2=Elettra|last3=Parisi|first3=Giuseppe|last4=Spinello|first4=Fabio|last5=Oldoni|first5=Matteo|last6=Ravanelli|first6=Roberto|last7=Coassini|first7=Piero|last8=Someda|first8=Carlo|last9=Thide|first9=Bo|last10=Romanato|first10=Filippo|year=2015|doi=10.1002/2015RS005662|volume=50|journal=Radio Nazionale di Elettromagnetismo|year=2014|location=Padua, Italy}} }}{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1434841116301005|title=Radio channel multiplexing with Propagation|volume=63|issue=10|pages=4582–4587|bibcode=2015ITAP...63.4582O|doi=10.1109/TAP.2015.2456953|last1=Oldoni|first1=Matteo|last10=Thide|first10=Bo}} Near field properties of OAM beams at microwaves have also been investigated{{cite journal|url=http://ieeexplore.ieee.org/xpl/articleDetails.jsp?arnumber=6953011|title=Near-Field Experimental Verification of Separation of OAM secure communications with application to contactless payments and transactions, filed under a dedicated patent.{{cite patent|inventor-last =Tamburini| inventor-first =Fabrizio| inventor2-last =Romanato| inventor2-first =Filippo| inventor3-last=Mari|inventor3-first=Elettra|inventor4-last=Someda|inventor4-first=Carlo|inventor5-last=Parisi|inventor5-first=Giuseppe|inventor6-last=Oldoni|inventor6-first=Matteo|inventor7-last=Spinello|inventor7-first=Fabio|inventor8-last=Coassini|inventor8-first=Piero|inventor9-last=Ravanelli|inventor9-first=Roberto|title=Metodo di comunicazione sicura a corto raggio|year=2016|url=https://www.google.com/patents/US20160292472|patent-number=US 20160292472}} The company continues its long standing cooperation strategy with research institutions and in 2015 it joined the Laurea Magistrale Plus program,{{Cite news|url=http://news.unipv.it/?page_id=9670|title=news.unipv – LM+|newspaper=news.unipv|access-date=2017-01-09}} promoted by [[University of Pavia]] for [[Master's degree]] achieved with an extended and close participation in existing companies' activities.{{Cite web|url=http://www.scuola24.ilsole24ore.com/art/universita-e-ricerca/2015-11-26/a-pavia-l-impresa-entra-ateneo--203113.php?uuid=ACmRn4hB|title=A Pavia l’impresa entra in ateneo|website=www.scuola24.ilsole24ore.com|access-date=2017-01-09}} In 2016 the company presented, at the [[Mobile World Congress]], [[MPLS VPN|Layer-3 VPN]] services over microwave radio links using SM-OS, based on [[Software-defined networking]] (SDN).http://www.ansa.it/sito/notizie/economia/business_wire/2016-02-22_1221378985.html{{Cite news|url=https://www.aricent.com/news/siae-microelettronica-and-aricent-showcasing-%E2%80%9Cnew-ip%E2%80%9D-over-sm-os-based-microwave-radio|title=SIAE MICROELETTRONICA and Aricent Showcasing "New IP" over SM-OS Based Microwave Radio Portfolio|date=2016-02-23|newspaper=Aricent|access-date=2017-01-05}} In 2016, an internal team of researchers coauthored the "Receiver", "Modem" and "Antenna" chapters in a comprehensive book describing electronic design of transceiver frontends for backhauling.{{Cite book|url=http://www.artechhouse.com/Main/Books/Electronics-for-Microwave-Backhaul-2311.aspx|title=Electronics for Microwave Backhaul|last=Camarchia|first=Vittorio|last2=Quaglia|first2=Roberto|last3=Pirola|first3=Marco|publisher=Artech House|year=2016|isbn=978-1-63081-015-3}} == Logos ==
File:Siae Logo 1952.gif|Logo of the newborn SIAE (Società Italiana Apparecchiature Elettroniche) company in 1952. The SIAE text is enclosed in a [[vacuum tube]]-like stencil used in schematics of electric circuits File:Microelettronica Logo, 1958.gif|Minimalistic textual logo of the newborn Microelettronica company in 1958 File:Siae Microelettronica Logo in 1963.gif|Textual logo of Siae Microelettronica company, created as result of merging the former Siae and Microelettronica companies in 1963 File:Siae Microelettronica Logo in 1968.gif|Logo of Siae Microelettronica in 1968, featuring a wider font than its predecessor File:Siae Microelettronica logo in 1970.gif|Graphical and textual logo in 1970. The symbol stylizes the initials S and M (for Siae and Micro) and a [[Cassegrain reflector]] antenna recalling the letter E (for Elettronica) File:Siae Microelettronica logo in 1990.jpg|Color graphical and textual logo, in use from 1990 until 2005. The SME stylized symbol is retained from the black and white 1970 version.
